a b s t r a c t
The design and synthesis of new hydrogen storage materials with high capacity are the prerequisite for extensive hydrogen energy application which can be achieved by multi-site hydrogen storage. Herein, a Mg@C60 nano-lamellae structure with multiple hydrogen storage sites has been prepared through a simple ball-milling process inwhichMgnanoparticles (~5 nm) are homogeneously dispersed on C60 nano-lamellae. The as-obtained C60/Mg nanolamellae displays an excess hydrogen uptake of 12.50 wt% at 45 bar, which is far higher than the theoretical value (7.60 wt%) of metal Mg and the US Department of Energy (DOE) target (5.50wt%, 2020 year), also the experimental values reported bynow. The enhancedhydrogen storage mainly comes from several storage sites: MgH2, HxeC60 (CeH chemical bonding), H2@C60 (the endohedral H2 in C60). Interestingly, the hybridization of Mg and C60 not only facilitate the dissociation of H2 molecules to form CeH bonding with C60, but also promote thedeformationof C60 andaccessH2molecules into the cavity ofC60. Thisworkprovides new insight into the underlying chemistry behind the high hydrogen storage capacities of a new class of hydrogen storage materials, fullerene/alkaline-earth metals nanocomposites.

Compared with covalent-organic materials (COMs) and MOFs, metal systems have been intensely examined due to their environmental benignity, high abundance, low cost, and excellent reversibility [7]. Metal magnesium (Mg), with a high theoretical gravimetric capacity of 7.6 wt%, has been considered as one of the most promising candidates for hydrogen storage. However, the actual hydrogen storage capacity for pure Mg metal can not meet the demand for extensive hydrogen energy application [8,9]. An effective approach to further enhance the hydrogen storage capacity forMg-basematerials is to constructmulti-site hydrogen storage by forminghybridmaterialswith lightweight materials [10,11]. Among these lightweight materials, carbonaceous materials are selected as the most suitable scaffold materials due to their lightweight, chemically inertness, good thermal conductivity andmechanically flexibility to withstand repeated volume change [12]. More importantly, H atoms dissociated on metallic surface can be transferred to carbon atoms to form CeH bonding, and the chemical inert carbon materials are converted to another hydrogen storage site [13]. SomeMg-carbonmaterials (e.g., Mg-doped graphene oxide and Mg-dopednanotubes) have been studied, andwhile promising, have been beset by mixed results, as shown in Table 1 [14,15]. The unusual physical and structural properties of the composite of fullerenes and light alkaline-earth metals have been elucidated from theoretical simulation studies because of the special hollow structure of C60 [16,17]. Detailed analysis shows that the charge redistribution in the composite gives rise to electric fields surrounding the coated fullerenes, which can bindhydrogenmolecules strongly through a polarization effect [18]. Furthermore, theoretically it is identified that C60, as an efficient hollow nanocontainer, can uptake massive hydrogen and exhibit a high theoretical capacity for hydrogen storage, which can be used as the potential site for hydrogen storage [19]. However, a corresponding simple method for introduce hydrogen into C60 is still on theway. In our lab's previouswork, it is found that the high-speed ball-milling treatment can induce the deformation of C60 structure and the deformation is maintained by the outside metal coating [20]. This indicates
that the deformation can open a door for hydrogen entering. Therefore, Mg coated C60 may display much enhanced hydrogen storage capacity due to multi-site hydrogen storage.
In this work, through a simple ball-milling process, (200) facets of C60 crystal are exfoliated and then coated bymetal Mg, resulting in a Mg@C60 nano-lamellae structure. The hydrogen pressure-composition (PC) isotherms show that the asobtained product displays a much enhanced hydrogen uptake of 12.50 wt% hydrogen, which is about 1.60 times the results for the maximal hydrogen storage capacities of both individual metal Mg and fullerenes nanoparticles [21e24]. In addition, its hydrogen uptake capacity is also the highest value reported so far. Different from the previous results, two saturation plateaus in its PC isotherm are observed because of the formation of MgH2, H@C60, which has been investigated in detail through density functional theory (DFT) calculations and the correlated spectrum analyses (e.g., X-ray diffraction patterns, Fourier transform infrared spectra, Raman spectra and 1H nuclear magnetic resonance spectra). The examinations show that the Mg@C60 nano-lamellae has special hydrogen storage patterns: Mg hydriding, partial hydriding of C60 through CeH bonding, and hydrogen trapping inside in deformed C60.

sections.heading: Experimental
sections.text: Preparation of Mg@C60 nanocomposites. C60 (purity 99.9%, Puyang Yongxin Fullerene Technology Co. Ltd) and Mg powders (purity 99.0%, 200 mesh, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd) were first blended together with different weight ratios: 1:1e1:5. All samples were ball-milled using a planetary ball mill (pulverizette 7, FRITSCH) in a zirconia (ZrO2) vessel with the inner volume of about 30 cm3 at a speed of 350 rounds per minute for 5 h under 1.0 MPa Ar gas atmosphere at room temperature. The ZrO2 balls with 2 mm in diameter were employed as ball-milling medium. The ball-to-powder weight ratio was 10:1. After cooling to room temperature, the asobtained powders were collected. All the handling processes were performed in a glove box (Miwa MFG, MP-P60W) filled with purified Ar gas (>99.9999%) to avoid oxidation. Theoretical calculations. First-principles density functional theory plus dispersion (DFT-D) calculations were performed using the DMol3 module [25,26]. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional was employed to describe the exchange and correlation effects [27]. An all electron double numerical atomic orbital augmented by double numerical plus polarization (DNP) 4.4 is used as the basis set. To calculate the minimum energy along the reaction paths we employ the linear/ quadratic synchronous transit (LST/QST) [28] and nudged elastic bond (NEB) [29] method in DMol3 code. These methodologies have been demonstrated as satisfactory tools to search for the structures of the transition states (TS) and the minimum energy pathways [30].

sections.heading: Results and discussion
sections.text:
In order to obtain Mg@C60 nanocomposites with good dispersion, detailed experiments with different milling speeds were
conducted (Fig. S1). According to the above SEM results, a suitable ball-milling speed, 350 r/min, is selected in this work. After that by changing the weight ratio of Mg to C60 (mC60:mMg ¼ 1:1 (Sample 1), 1:2 (Sample 2), 1:3 (Sample 3), 1:4 (Sample 4), 1:5 (Sample 5)), samples with minimized particle size and maximized interfaces between C60 and metal Mg are obtained. By comparsion their representative SEM images in Fig. S2 and the nanoparticle's sizes (Table S1), it can be seen that the minimum particle size (~25 nm) are obtained in Sample 3, and the agglomeration of the carbon materials and Mg can be clearly observed in other samples. This result also agrees with the BET results (Table S1), in which Sample 3 exhibits a largest specific surface area: 50.39 m2/g. The overall composition and crystal structure of the as-synthesized samples are then investigated by XRD measurements, as shown in Fig. S3a. The XRD patterns confirm that the raw Mg is hcp phase (JCPDS No. 35e0821) and the original C60 used by us is a pure faced-center cubic (fcc) phase (JCPDS No. 81e2220). After ball-milling the rawmaterials for several hours under Ar atmosphere, it is found that all diffraction peaks corresponding to Mg and C60 crystal are broadened due to the refining effect induced by the ball-milling process. Noticeably, (111) peak of C60 crystal shifts left to lower degree, implying enlarged interlayer distance, which also agrees with the phenomena reported in previouswork about the exfoliation of two-dimensional molecular crystals like graphene and molybdenumdisulfide [31,32]. The formation process of Sample 3 is further investigated through TEM and HRTEM examinations. As shown in Fig. 1, with the ball-milling proceeding, (200) facets of C60 crystal are stripped off and new C60 nanolamellae is formed with about four (200) layers when the ball-milling time is up to 3 h. After ball-milled for 5 h, defined Mg nanoparticles (3e5 nm) are coated on the above as-formed C60 layers, resulting in Mg@C60 nano-lamellae composite. As expected, HRTEM examinations (Fig. 1f and g) and EDX analysis (Fig. 1h, i and j) of the particle clearly confirm the formation of Mg@C60 nano-lamellae. On the basis of the above results and analysis, the formation process of Mg@C60 nanostructures is concluded and shown in Fig. 1a.
Raman spectroscopy and infrared spectroscopy measurements of Sample 3 have been further conducted to confirm the composition of Mg@C60 nano-lamellae, as shown in Fig. S4. The spectra of the composite show that C60 exists in the product and there are no peaks from other impurities, such as amorphous carbon, thus indicating that C60 molecules aren't broken down. Moreover, the increased number of peaks in the Raman spectrum and several new modes in the region between 700 and 900 cm 1 of infrared transmission spectra also indicate a symmetry-reduced C60 molecule: in other word, the C60 molecule is deformed, indicating that the a door maybe opened on C60 for hydrogen entering.
The hydrogen storage properties of theMg@C60 composites are evaluated using PC isotherm measurements, TG and DSC, respectively. Fig. 2 shows the dependence of the hydrogen adsorption and desorption on the pressure for the as-prepared composites with different Mg to C60 wt ratios under Ar gas atmosphere. Interestingly, except Sample 5 with more metal Mg content, the other four samples show two saturation plateaus in the hydrogen adsorption processes, which is very different from the results with only one plateau in the
literature [33]. As anticipated by us, the hydrogen adsorption capacity of Sample 3 is much enhanced in comparison to those of other samples. As presented in Fig. 2a, H2 adsorption measurement result of Sample 3 exhibits an excess H2 uptake of 12.50 wt% at 45 bar, representing the highest H2 uptake value according to the literature reported for metal/carbon composites. For Sample 3, the isotherms show a steep increase (~6.2 wt% hydrogen storage) after the first saturation plateau (~6.29 wt% hydrogen storage) in the excess hydrogen uptake. So the detailed composition, purity and crystal structure of Sample 3 after hydrogen adsorption are then investigated by XRD and FT-IR measurements, as shown in Fig. S5. The XRD pattern (Fig. S5a) shows that after the hydrogen adsorption, all the diffraction peaks except those from C60 crystal (unchanged compared with that before hydriding), can be indexed as a pure MgH2 (JCPDS No.74e0934), without metal Mg. Its corresponding FT-IR spectrum (Fig. S5b) also shows two regions of active infrared vibrations of the MgeH bonds. After that, it is further studied by XPS measurements, as shown in Fig. S6. Except the peaks corresponding to Mg2þ (for example: 1304.5 eV for the binding energy of Mg 1s (Fig. S6b), 89.1 eV assigned to Mg 2s (Fig. S6c) and 50.2 eV for Mg 2p (Fig. S6d)), there is no peak for metal Mg [34]. Additionally, many CeH chemical bonds are also found in Fig. S5b, which is very different from the result before hydriding (Fig. S4b). The above results prove that metal Mg in Sample 3 is completely transformed to MgH2 and C60 is also hydrogenated during the adsorption process. Compared with the previous hydriding conditions, such as temperature and pressure, needed bymetal Mg [35], there are reasons to believe that the first saturation plateau in the hydrogen adsorption process is due to the formation of MgH2. This is also proved by the following examinations. So, the second one should belong to the hydriding of C60. Then, this work shows that almost all the hydrogen from MgH2 in Sample 3 can be released at reasonable pressures, as shown in Fig. 2b. Under a PC isotherm measurement (300 C, the highest temperature safety limit of the measurement equipment), about 6.29 wt% hydrogen is released under low pressure, which is equal to the adsorption value of the first saturation plateau (Fig. 2a). This is also investigated by the corresponding XRD and FT-IR measurements. As shown in Fig. S7a, after the above dehydrogenation process, all the MgH2 is transformed back to metal Mg according to its XRD pattern. At the same time, the sample's FT-IR spectrum (Fig. S7b) also shows that there is no MgH2 existed. Furthermore, obvious CeH bonds are found, so the H atoms adsorbed by C60 are still reserved. This is because the hydrogen desorption from the CeH bonds usually requires relatively higher temperature [36]. To release the residual hydrogen, DSC and TG measurements of the above sample (without MgH2 after the PC isotherm measurement), are performed, as shown in Fig. S8. An endothermic reaction appeared at 462 C is found and simultaneously a ~6.20 wt% weight loss of the sample is observed, which agrees well with the hydrogen adsorption value of the second saturation plateau in Fig. 2a. Exhilaratingly, as shown in Fig. 3, the 1H NMR spectrum of the Sample 3 after the adsorption process exhibits a noticeable signal at d ¼ 1.14 ppm, which is belonged to the H2@C60 (the endohedral H2 in C60) and proves the successful introduction of hydrogen into C60 [37,38]. So in
this work we provide a very simple method to realize the endohedral H2 in C60. Furthermore, the 1H NMR spectrum shows a signal at d ¼ 5.93 ppm of the C60H2 (C60 hydrocarbon derivative) [39] and a signal of the MgH2 at d ¼ 2.75 ppm [40]. Then the overall hydrogen desorption of the Sample 3 with hydrogen is also studied by DSC and TG measurements (Fig. S9), which displays two endothermic peaks at 285 C and 462 C and simultaneously a totally ~12.49 wt% weight loss of the sample. This indicates that almost all the hydrogen stored in the sample can be released only above 462 C. XRD and FT-
IR measurements are also performed for the product after TG examination. The XRD result (Fig. S10a) confirms the recovery of C60 and metal Mg after the desorption process. Its FT-IR spectrum (Fig. S10b) validates the above result, though there are some residual CeH bonds. All the above measurements proved that Mg@C60 nano-lamellae is an outstanding hydrogen storage material with amazing high capacity.
The above hydrogenation process and mechanism is also investigated by DFT-D calculations. As shown in Fig. S11, through the theoretical analysis, it is found that the diffusion
energy barrier of H in bulk Mg is apparently higher than that on the Mg surface and thus H diffusion is faster on the metal surface. However, interfacial reaction for H atom crossing a few Mg atoms layer is still more prone to occur relative to the HeH bond cleavage in the pure gas phase. Therefore, a significant decrease in Mg particle size in this work promotes the hydriding reaction. Interestingly, after the first saturation plateau in the excess hydrogen uptake, the isotherms except that of Sample 5 with more Mg content, exhibit a suddenly increase and the second saturation plateau under elevated hydrogen pressures appear, which indicates that more hydrogenwith amax ~6 wt% amount has been untaken in the products, as shown in Fig. 2. The corresponding FT-IR spectrum (Fig. S5b) indicates an additional formation of CeH bonds compared with that of the sample before hydrogenation (Fig. S4b). The formation of CeHbonds needsH atoms and C60 is inert for the dissociation of hydrogen molecules, while Mg can act as a catalyst to promote dissociation of hydrogen molecules to form MgH2. This phenomenon is also studied in detail by DFT-D calculations. As shown in Fig. 4a, the calculated H2 dissociation barrier on the C60 surface of 295.5 kJ/mol
is well above that of H2 dissociation on theMg surface. A cause for the high transient state (TS) energy is the longer HeH distance in the structure of the TS for the C60eH2 system (1.605 A) relative to that for H2 dissociation on Mg surface (1.073 A) as well as the weak CeH bonding effect at a distance of 1.137 A. As to the Mg effect on the association between H2 and C60, the calculations show that Mg cannot bond with C60 to form a stable structure. This comes from the lack of a valence d electron in Mg. However, the weak intermolecular interaction and malleable property of Mg allows itself to form a wrapping structure on C60 as shown in Fig. 4b. This is in accord with the experimental observation shown in Fig. 1. Such a structure permits a good contact between Mg and C60 and provides spacious interfaces between C60 and Mg for the diffusion and adsorption of H atoms. The adsorption amount depends on the three dimensionalmorphology of themixture. The predicted energy barrier of the subsequent reaction between C60 and hydrogen atoms in the presence of Mg is reduced to 114.7 kJ/mol, as shown in Fig. 4c. Thus, the association reaction of C60eH is actually promoted bymetal Mg. As a result, the lowered barrier becomes close to that of H2 dissociation on Mg (97.3 kJ/mol, as shown in Fig. S11a). It is worth noting that the energy of the product for the C60eH association reaction is higher than that of the reactants, which means the reverse reaction i.e. the dehydrogenation can occur spontaneously at ambient conditions. Therefore, the residual hydrogen in the form of CeH bonding found in Fig. S10 should exist at the sites far away the interface of Mg and C60. Additionally, the C60 hydrogenation reaction should only occur under enough high H2 pressure, which is consistent with our experimental results (Fig. 2a).
It is well-known that the addition of H atoms to C60, the primary C]C is converted to CeC, and the bond length is stretchedwhichmay further aggravate the deformation of C60 [41]. To further investigate the correlation of the hydrogenation and structural deformation of C60, we also carry out the final C60 structure after hydrogenation reaction by theoretical calculation. As shown in Fig. S12, it is found that with the addition of H atoms to C60, the distance of diagonal line for the fundamental hexatomic ring is extended from 2.85 to 2.99 (two H atoms) and 3.17 A (six H atoms), respectively. Undoubtedly, the hydrogenation of C60 can promote the
deformation of C60 and make the possibility of H2 enter into the cavity of C60. It can be readily deduced that a high pressure of H2 gas is required since the opening of C60 cages proceeds only when enough C atoms in C60 are activated for bond breaking by H2 molecules, which is consistent with the experimental phenomenon that the hydrogen content doubles at the pressures higher than 45 bar. In addition, the microstructure of the Mg@C60 nano-lamellae also plays an important role in hydrogen storage, which is mainly determined by the mass ratio of the components and preparation procedures. This is consistent with the observation that the 1:3 ratio of C60 and Mg is crucial to maximize the capacity.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text: In summary, Mg@C60 nano-lamellae have been successfully prepared via a direct high-energy ball-milling method. The hybridization of Mg and C60 makes the structure deformation of C60 in the high energy ball-milling process. The dispersed Mgnanoparticles facilitate hydrogenmolecules dissociate and transfer H atoms to adjacent C60 molecules to form CeH bonding. Benefiting from structure deformation of C60 and Ce H bonding, hydrogen molecules can access the cavity of C60 and the hollow C60molecules can act as new hydrogen storage site for the first time. Due to the multi-site hydrogen storage, the Mg@C60 nano-lamellae achieves a striking hydrogen storage capacity (up to 12.49 wt%) at an accessible pressure (at 45 bar). This composite provide high storage capacity of hydrogen without unwanted by-product materials. Hence, this work is expected to advance and promote the progress for new high capacity hydrogen storage media.

metadata.abstractText: The design and synthesis of new hydrogen storage materials with high capacity are the prerequisite for extensive hydrogen energy application which can be achieved by multi-site hydrogen storage. Herein, a Mg@C60 nano-lamellae structure with multiple hydrogen storage sites has been prepared through a simple ball-milling process inwhichMgnanoparticles (~5 nm) are homogeneously dispersed on C60 nano-lamellae. The as-obtained C60/Mg nanolamellae displays an excess hydrogen uptake of 12.50 wt% at 45 bar, which is far higher than the theoretical value (7.60 wt%) of metal Mg and the US Department of Energy (DOE) target (5.50wt%, 2020 year), also the experimental values reported bynow. The enhancedhydrogen storage mainly comes from several storage sites: MgH2, HxeC60 (CeH chemical bonding), H2@C60 (the endohedral H2 in C60). Interestingly, the hybridization of Mg and C60 not only facilitate the dissociation of H2 molecules to form CeH bonding with C60, but also promote thedeformationof C60 andaccessH2molecules into the cavity ofC60. Thisworkprovides new insight into the underlying chemistry behind the high hydrogen storage capacities of a new class of hydrogen storage materials, fullerene/alkaline-earth metals nanocomposites. © 2019 Hydrogen Energy Publications LLC. Compared with covalent-organic materials (COMs) and MOFs, metal systems have been intensely examined due to their environmental benignity, high abundance, low cost, and excellent reversibility [7]. Metal magnesium (Mg), with a high theoretical gravimetric capacity of 7.6 wt%, has been considered as one of the most promising candidates for hydrogen storage. However, the actual hydrogen storage capacity for pure Mg metal can not meet the demand for extensive hydrogen energy application [8,9]. An effective approach to further enhance the hydrogen storage capacity forMg-basematerials is to constructmulti-site hydrogen storage by forminghybridmaterialswith lightweight materials [10,11]. Among these lightweight materials, carbonaceous materials are selected as the most suitable scaffold materials due to their lightweight, chemically inertness, good thermal conductivity andmechanically flexibility to withstand repeated volume change [12]. More importantly, H atoms dissociated on metallic surface can be transferred to carbon atoms to form CeH bonding, and the chemical inert carbon materials are converted to another hydrogen storage site [13]. SomeMg-carbonmaterials (e.g., Mg-doped graphene oxide and Mg-dopednanotubes) have been studied, andwhile promising, have been beset by mixed results, as shown in Table 1 [14,15]. The unusual physical and structural properties of the composite of fullerenes and light alkaline-earth metals have been elucidated from theoretical simulation studies because of the special hollow structure of C60 [16,17]. Detailed analysis shows that the charge redistribution in the composite gives rise to electric fields surrounding the coated fullerenes, which can bindhydrogenmolecules strongly through a polarization effect [18]. Furthermore, theoretically it is identified that C60, as an efficient hollow nanocontainer, can uptake massive hydrogen and exhibit a high theoretical capacity for hydrogen storage, which can be used as the potential site for hydrogen storage [19]. However, a corresponding simple method for introduce hydrogen into C60 is still on theway. In our lab's previouswork, it is found that the high-speed ball-milling treatment can induce the deformation of C60 structure and the deformation is maintained by the outside metal coating [20]. This indicates that the deformation can open a door for hydrogen entering. Therefore, Mg coated C60 may display much enhanced hydrogen storage capacity due to multi-site hydrogen storage. In this work, through a simple ball-milling process, (200) facets of C60 crystal are exfoliated and then coated bymetal Mg, resulting in a Mg@C60 nano-lamellae structure. The hydrogen pressure-composition (PC) isotherms show that the asobtained product displays a much enhanced hydrogen uptake of 12.50 wt% hydrogen, which is about 1.60 times the results for the maximal hydrogen storage capacities of both individual metal Mg and fullerenes nanoparticles [21e24]. In addition, its hydrogen uptake capacity is also the highest value reported so far. Different from the previous results, two saturation plateaus in its PC isotherm are observed because of the formation of MgH2, H@C60, which has been investigated in detail through density functional theory (DFT) calculations and the correlated spectrum analyses (e.g., X-ray diffraction patterns, Fourier transform infrared spectra, Raman spectra and H nuclear magnetic resonance spectra). The examinations show that the Mg@C60 nano-lamellae has special hydrogen storage patterns: Mg hydriding, partial hydriding of C60 through CeH bonding, and hydrogen trapping inside in deformed C60.
